metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Templates let you write a function or class that works with different data types.
content.html: Templates let you write a function or class that works with different data types.

content.text: They help avoid repeating code and make programs more flexible.
content.html: They help avoid repeating code and make programs more flexible.

content.text: You can create a function template by using the template keyword:
content.html: You can create a function template by using the template keyword:

content.code_html:
template <typename T>
return_type function_name(T parameter) {
  // code
}

template <typename T>
T add(T a, T b) {
  return a + b;
}

int main() {
  cout << add<int>(5, 3) << "\n";
  cout << add<double>(2.5, 1.5) << "\n";
  return 0;
}

content.text: In the example above, add <int>(5, 3) tells the compiler to use int for T , while add <double>(2.5, 1.5) tells it to use double .
content.html: In the example above, add<int>(5, 3) tells the compiler to use int for T, while add<double>(2.5, 1.5) tells it to use double.

content.text: You can also use templates to make classes that work with any data type:
content.html: You can also use templates to make classes that work with any data type:

content.code_html:
template <typename T>
class ClassName {
  // members and methods using T
};

content.text: The example below defines a template class Box that can store and display a value of any data type, and then creates one box for an int and one for a string :
content.html: The example below defines a template class Box that can store and display a value of any data type, and then creates one box for an int and one for a string:

content.code_html:
template <typename T>
class Box {
  public:
    T value;
    Box(T v) {
      value = v;
    }
    void show() {
      cout << "Value: " << value << "\n";
    }
};

int main() {
  Box<int> intBox(50);
  Box<string> strBox("Hello");

  intBox.show();
  strBox.show();
  return 0;
}

content.text: And this example defines a template class Pair that stores two values of different types and displays them, then creates one pair for a person's name and age, and another for an ID and score:
content.html: And this example defines a template class Pair that stores two values of different types and displays them, then creates one pair for a person's name and age, and another for an ID and score:

content.code_html:
template <typename T1, typename T2>
class Pair {
  public:
    T1 first;
    T2 second;

    Pair(T1 a, T2 b) {
      first = a;
      second = b;
    }

    void display() {
      cout << "First: " << first << ", Second: " << second << "\n";
    }
};

int main() {
  Pair<string, int> person("John", 30);
  Pair<int, double> score(51, 9.5);

  person.display();
  score.display();

  return 0;
}

content.text: Note: Templates must be defined in the same file where they are used (usually in the .h file).
content.html: Note: Templates must be defined in the same file where they are used (usually in the .h file).
